snippet: Recent disclosures of American spying reflect the complicated nature of the relationship between the intelligence services of the United States and its allies.
abstract: Intelligence experts and historians say recent disclosures of American spying by Edward J Snowden reflect complicated relationship between intelligence services of United States and its allies, which have long quietly swapped information on one another's citizens.

byline.contributor: Stephen Castle contributed reporting from London, Scott Sayare from Paris, and Eric Schmitt from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Recent disclosures of American spying reflect the complicated nature of the relationship between the intelligence services of the United States and its allies.

headline.main: For Western Allies, a Long History of Swapping Intelligence
headline.print_headline: Allies Share a Long History of Swapping Intelligence
